item.title: Anti-descriptivism
item.description: Opposition to descriptivism. [-@@scharp2012wilfrid] Relevant figures: Saul Kripke Hilary Putnam David Kaplan Wilfrid Sellars Topics: semantic externalism epistemological externalism functionalism direct reference the relation between conceivability and possibility Consequences:

item.title: Declarativism
item.description: All declarative sentences should be put in a box, i.e. given a uniform semantics. Furthermore, this semantics should be that they should be thought of as “fact-stating”, a paradigm example being “the frog is on the log”.

item.title: Emotivism
item.description: How can we, in our modern scientific world, come to know moral facts? This is a problem of moral skepticism.

item.title: Logical empiricism
item.description: Ideology associated with the Vienna Circle.

item.title: Naturalism
item.description: Advanced by Huw Price’s distinction of Object naturalism and subjective naturalism.

item.title: Representationalism
item.description: A theory of semantics, closely related to descriptivism: to be cognitively contentful is to be representing the world. E.g. Demonstratives, indexicals, Proper names, natural kind terms can be thought of as representing without being descriptions, e.
